facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras.

facts.text: The reference was made to the High Court by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, section 23A was properly applied ?

anchor.surface_text: The following question of law was referred. Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, section 23A was properly applied ? The relevant facts and circumstances are as follows.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All conditions of section 23A satisfied: dividend declared less than 60% of assessable income minus taxes; not unreasonable to declare larger dividend given material of concealed income and manipulated accounts before ITO.

holdings.text: The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits; additions in respect of luggage collections and expenditure on spare parts, tyres, tubes, etc., disallowed had to be added to the book profits

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree to this contention. The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits. In our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that these two items had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the true commercial or accounting profits of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits made under section 23A refer to true commercial profits, not merely book profits; deliberately omitted or inflated items reflect real profits known to directors.

holdings.text: Once ITO satisfied that dividends less than 60% of assessable income reduced by taxes and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute larger dividend, ITO has no option but to deem undistributed portion as distributed dividend

anchor.surface_text: but once the Income-tax Officer is satisfied that in respect of any previous year the profits and gains distributed as dividend by any company are less than 60 of the assessable income of the previous year, as reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the assessee in respect thereof, and that it would not be unreasonable to distribute a larger dividend than that declared, he has no option but to pass an order that the undistributed portion of the assessable income of the assessee of the previous year, as computed for income-tax purposes and reduced by the amount of income-tax and super-tax payable by the company, shall be deemed to have been distributed as dividend amongst the shareholders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory language of section 23A leaves no discretion upon satisfaction of twin conditions.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer did not consider the question of reasonableness of dividend from standpoint of business considerations like prudent businessman
holdings.reasoning_summary: ITO's order focused on figures and book vs assessable income differences without explicit reference to previous losses, surplus availability, future needs as required by precedent.

holdings.text: Burden lies on revenue to prove satisfaction of all section 23A conditions including unreasonableness assessment, but here discharged by evidence of concealed profits and improper accounts
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Gangadhar Banerjee accepted; burden met as manipulated accounts and concealed income (luggage, spares) provided material for unreasonableness finding despite incomplete consideration by ITO.

holdings.text: It is not too late to permit assessee to raise point on business considerations for reasonableness under section 23A

anchor.surface_text: We feel that it is not too late to permit him to raise this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court permits consideration despite not raised before AAC or Tribunal.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee company Would the satisfaction of the Income-tax Officer depend only on the two circumstances, namely, losses and smallness of profit ?

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Gangadhar Banerjee & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: reasonableness of dividend distribution judged by business considerations such as previous losses, present profits, availability of surplus money, reasonable requirements of the future; ITO must take overall picture of financial position of business
precedents.cited_holding: The Income-tax Officer, acting under this section, is not assessing any income to tax that will be assessed in the hands of the shareholders. He only does what the directors should have done. He puts himself in the place of the directors. Though the object of the section is to prevent evasion of tax, the provision must be worked not from the standpoint of the tax collector but from that of a businessman.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree to this contention. The commercial or accounting profits which have to be taken into consideration are the real commercial or accounting profits. If an item is deliberately omitted from the accounts, it cannot be said that commercial principles prevent that amount being added to the profits in order to arrive at the real commercial or accounting profits. In our opinion, the High Court was right in holding that these two items had to be added to the book profits in order to arrive at the true commercial or accounting profits of the assessee.
In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.
In the result, we agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative.
